stream_context.summary: Kaze began the stream by debugging a persistent crash in the game's main area, which he traced to a faulty coin formation actor. After fixing it, he transitioned to designing a new retro level for 'Course 13' based on Super Mario Land 1. He and his community brainstormed ideas, settling on translating the plane level into a 3D on-rails shooter, and he began creating the initial 3D models for it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a persistent crash by isolating the cause to a specific coin formation actor, discovering that a recent UV-mapping operation had unintentionally broken the object's geometry.
development_findings.quote: This was the cause for the crash... Oh, because I projected everything. These are no longer done. Fuuuuck. I just undid a lot of work.

development_findings.summary: The project has a strict creative rule that all retro-themed levels must be based on games that were released before Super Mario 64 to maintain a consistent time-period aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: Why not doing anything that released after Mario 64, maybe? That's the rule. We want it to fit in the time.

development_findings.summary: The Super Mario Land 1 level is being designed as an on-rails shooter, translating the original 2D gameplay into a 3D space with a fixed camera and movement restricted to the 2D screen plane.
development_findings.quote: It will be forced perspective. The camera will be permanently stuck like this. Then you're allowed to move in screen space, but you're not allowed to move the location of the camera.

development_findings.summary: The project will require the Gliden graphics plugin to be playable, as Kaze has dismissed other renderers like Parallel as unworkable for his purposes.
Kaze began modeling a 3D version of Mario's plane from Super Mario Land 1, basing it on the original 16x16 pixel sprite to serve as the player vehicle in the new on-rails level.
A level based on Yoshi's Story was previously planned but was ultimately cut from the project because the team decided it was 'unfitting' for the game's overall vision.
To create the effect of an endless sky in the on-rails level, Kaze is building a long, enclosed corridor with fog, as a true skybox or solid color background is not easily supported by the engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is increasing his streaming schedule to earn more money in preparation for having a child, stating he is very efficient while working on stream.
context_findings.quote: I got three whole months of it long for having a child. But also, I need to work more because I want to make more money. So that's why I'm gonna just stream like basically every day now.

context_findings.summary: If Kaze could go back to 1995, his first change to the original Super Mario 64 would be to optimize the rendering code for better performance, believing it would have made adding Luigi a trivial task.
context_findings.quote: The first thing I do is fix the graph render code. Make it all fit into one block of cache. And now the entire game runs at 30 FPS. And we can add Luigi to the game. And it's going to be two days of work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally develops for a single emulator (Project64 with Gliden) because he has already invested the time to learn and work around its specific bugs, and supporting another would double that workload.
context_findings.quote: Every emulator is broken as fuck. It's just that I've been using this emulator because this one is the easiest one to use... If I wanted to support a second emulator, I would have to also work around all the bugs in that emulator.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's personal nostalgia for Super Mario Land 1 is the primary reason for its inclusion as a retro level, overriding suggestions for other games.
context_findings.quote: I haven't played Land 2 as a child. So for me, Land 1 is like the only one that I will have some nostalgia for.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's parents are visiting for ten days, which he describes as a significant amount of work, including spending hours doing yard work with his father.

biobak.summary: Biobak participated in the brainstorming for the retro level, suggesting Super Mario Land 3 as a possibility before Kaze settled on Super Mario Land 1.

zeina.summary: Kaze refers to his wife (Zeina) during a 'meme reveal' on his desktop, indicating their personal relationship but not offering insight into their professional collaboration in this stream.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Coin Formation Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze encountered a persistent crash in the game's main area. Through a process of elimination, he deduced the problem was not collision data but a specific coin formation actor that had been inadvertently broken by a previous UV mapping operation.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent and unknown crash was preventing the game from loading properly, halting development.
key_stories.process: Kaze first hypothesized the crash was due to too many collision triangles. When removing them didn't work, he correctly deduced it was an actor. He then systematically investigated objects, pinpointing a specific coin formation that was broken by a recent, unrelated UV-mapping operation.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified the specific coin formation actor causing the crash, allowing him to fix the issue and resume development on the level.
key_stories.key_quote: This was the cause for the crash. I thought I had the top of these already done. Am I literally insane?

key_stories.title: Translating Super Mario Land 1 into 3D
key_stories.summary: To create a unique level based on Super Mario Land 1, Kaze decided against a simple platformer. He chose the plane level and designed a new gameplay style for it: a 3D on-rails shooter with a fixed camera, translating the 2D experience into a new format while retaining the original's aesthetic.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to create a retro level for Super Mario Land 1 but wanted to avoid making a simple 2D platformer clone or a concept that was difficult to execute, like a submarine level requiring many new front-facing sprites.
key_stories.process: Kaze, with input from Biobak and chat, brainstormed ideas. He rejected a submarine level due to asset creation challenges and settled on the plane level (4-3). He then designed a new gameplay mechanic, translating the 2D shooter into a 3D on-rails format with a fixed camera.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design direction was established: the level will be a 3D on-rails shooter, using the black-and-white aesthetic of the original but offering a new gameplay experience. Kaze began creating the core assets for this new design.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want to make the same game, but worse... It will be forced perspective. The camera will be permanently stuck like this. Then you're allowed to move in screen space.
